Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Package Signing] Add Service Bus Integration between Validators and Jobs" (#4810) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Merged pull request "Add branding test" (#4809) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4714
Adds a configurable functional test for customized branding.
Falls back to default branding if no custom options are used.

@joelverhagen @skofman1 @shishirx34

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Include richer statistics for package downloads" (#4808) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently we can get number of downloads per package and how they were downloaded. But there is more that could be included that will help developers measure different metrics. 

For example, how many are updates from an earlier version and how many are new installs to an existing or new project. What about distinguishing between a download that has been initiated by the user vs a download that has been pulled down because it is a dependency on another nuget (bonus for what nuget). 

This data in addition to the existing statistics van help interpolate any data we would need.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Validation of newly uploaded packages" (#167) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Smoke test newly uploaded packages to ensure packages meet basic standards.

This also increases overall package quality on the gallery and mitigates risks such as defined in http://nuget.codeplex.com/workitem/1686

Maybe add some recommendations as well? (e.g. your package seems to be larger than average, consider splitting your package into multiple ones with proper dependencies if individual components can be used without requiring the full package contents)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Include richer statistics for package downloads" (#4808) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently we can get number of downloads per package and how they were downloaded. But there is more that could be included that will help developers measure different metrics. 

For example, how many are updates from an earlier version and how many are new installs to an existing or new project. What about distinguishing between a download that has been initiated by the user vs a download that has been pulled down because it is a dependency on another nuget (bonus for what nuget). 

This data in addition to the existing statistics van help interpolate any data we would need.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Fix caching of static files." (#4776) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Build action not applying to contentFiles" (#6000) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Dear Nuget community,

I've been stuck for some time now and I need your help. I've been trying to solve a single problem: attach a .dll file to a project (as a content). I had a relatively easy way placing it as a content, but having it as an Embedded Resource just doesn't work! It places the file in the correct place, but sets the Build Action to "Content".

I've read and followed the [official documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/schema/nuspec) and placed a <contentFiles> section in the metadata, but it's still not working.

I've attached my .nuspec file (with files names changed, for privacy):

myNuspec.nuspec (changed the extension to .txt so I could upload the file):
[myNuspec.1.0.0.0.txt](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1363579/myNuspec.1.0.0.0.txt)

Bellow I've placed the data recommended:

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe
NuGet version: 4.1.0.2450
dotnet.exe --version: 1.1.0
VS version: Professional 2017
OS version: Windows 10.0.14393.1715 (v1607) [can't update]

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "<NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn> ignored on project reference" (#5999) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@mafalarz reported this issue here: https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/869

<NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn> ignored on project reference

Despite adding the` <NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn>` on all my project reference like this:
```
<ProjectReference Include="..\Reports\Reports.csproj">
   <NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn>
</ProjectReference>
```
I still get the warning message 

> NU1701: Package 'Teradata.Net.Data.Provider 15.11.0.1' was restored using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.6.1' instead of the project target framework '.NETStandard,Version=v2.0'. This package may not be fully compatible with your project.

Also on publishing Nugget and adding <`NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn` to my nugget package:

```
> <PackageReference Include="Carbon.ClientQueries" Version="0.0.1.16-Preview">
>       <NoWarn>NU1701</NoWarn>
> </PackageReference>
```
I keep getting warning: 

> NU1701: Package 'Teradata.Net.Data.Provider 15.11.0.1' was restored using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.6.1' instead of the project target framework '.NETStandard,Version=v2.0'. This package may not be fully compatible with your project. 

I think this is because my nugget has a reference to a project reference of my solution like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30442378/29490081-a77ebd2c-84ff-11e7-8c6c-e2514d4e2b71.png)

We need docs for AssetTargetFallback, both generally and migrating from PackageTargetFallback .

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Reinstalling a single package causes reinstallation of every package in the solution" (#5997) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

After retargetting a project to a different .NET version, I followed the instructions to reinstall some packages. Instead of reinstalling a single package, it reinstalled every package in the solution.

NuGet product used: Package Manager Console

NuGet version: NuGet Package Manager 4.3.1, Package Manager Console Host Version 4.3.1.4445

VS version: Enterprise 2017

OS version: win10 v1607 (14393.1715)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: n/a

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Retarget a project from v4.5.2 to v4.6.1, in a solution containing multiple projects

2. Observe the following error: 
    > Some NuGet packages were installed using a target framework different from the current target framework and may need to be reinstalled. Visit http://docs.nuget.org/docs/workflows/reinstalling-packages for more information.  Packages affected: System.IO.Compression, System.Net.Http, System.Xml.ReaderWriter

3. Open the Package Manager Console and execute the following command, as is described [in the docs referred to by the error](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/nuget/consume-packages/reinstalling-and-updating-packages#using-update-package):
    `PM> Update-Package -Id System.Net.Http -reinstall`

4. Observe NuGet reinstalling every package for every project in the solution, including the execution of `install.ps1` scripts. It took a total of 1m32s in my case, and and even reinstalled packages like jQuery and Bootstrap in one of the projects:
    ```
    Removed package 'bootstrap 3.0.0' from 'packages.config'
    Skipping 'C:\<redacted>\Scripts\bootstrap.js' because it was modified.
    Skipping 'C:\<redacted>\Scripts\bootstrap.min.js' because it was modified.
    Successfully uninstalled 'bootstrap 3.0.0' from <redacted>
    Executing script file 'C:\<redacted>\packages\jQuery.1.10.2\Tools\uninstall.ps1'
    Skipping 'Scripts\jquery-1.10.2.intellisense.js' because it was modified.
    Removed package 'jQuery 1.10.2' from 'packages.config'
    Successfully uninstalled 'jQuery 1.10.2' from <redacted>
    Removed package 'Antlr 3.4.1.9004' from 'packages.config'
    Successfully uninstalled 'Antlr 3.4.1.9004' from <redacted>
    Package 'Antlr.3.4.1.9004' already exists in folder 'C:\<redacted>\packages'
    Added package 'Antlr.3.4.1.9004' to 'packages.config'
    Successfully installed 'Antlr 3.4.1.9004' to <redacted>
    Package 'jQuery.1.10.2' already exists in folder 'C:\<redacted>\packages'
    Added package 'jQuery.1.10.2' to 'packages.config'
    Executing script file 'C:\<redacted>\packages\jQuery.1.10.2\Tools\install.ps1'
    Successfully installed 'jQuery 1.10.2' to <redacted>
    Package 'bootstrap.3.0.0' already exists in folder 'C:\<redacted>\packages'
    File Conflict
    File 'Scripts\bootstrap.min.js' already exists in project '<redacted>'. Do you want to overwrite it?
    [Y] Yes  [A] Yes to All  [N] No  [L] No to All  [?] Help (default is "N"):l
    'Scripts\bootstrap.min.js' already exists. Skipping...
    'Scripts\bootstrap.js' already exists. Skipping...
    ```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "References are not updated properly for a csproj files." (#5996) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello. 
The problem can be reproduced only sometimes. Visual studio 2013 and Visual studio 2015.

Nuget version: 4.3.0.4168
```

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <solution>
    <add key="disableSourceControlIntegration" value="true" />
  </solution>
</configuration>
```

We have few big solutions with many projects in it. 
And sometimes references are not updated properly. 
Some files are updated ok and  some not. 
I cannot find any regularities.

Example (the csproj file):
```

    <Reference Include="Contracts, Version=**2.4.200.0**, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b35cbb71b63bcbcf, processorArchitecture=MSIL">
     <HintPath>..\..\packages\Contracts.**2.4.203.0**\lib\net35\PosConfiguration.Contracts.dll</HintPath>
      <Private>True</Private>
    </Reference>
```

See that Include and Hint Path has different versions!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Assets from packages are missing after restore" (#5995) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Some users have reported that after restoring assets such as System.Runtime are missing from the assets file.

This is potentially caused by restore happening while the fallback folder is still being created. The problem is made much worse by how restore reuses file lists from previous restores for the next restore. To improve this experience restore should read the files from disk each time instead of from the previous assets file.

Note that if the fallback folder from the CLI is corrupt then this should be fixed there also.

See: https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/920

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Markdown based documentation for packages" (#9) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing support for rich markdown based documentation for packages

This feature has following parts:
**1. Ability to associate a markdown documentation to packages (and existing packages)
2. Understand markdown and render it properly on NuGet.org package details page**
3. Ability to associate markdown documentation content while packing the package, from clients
4. Ability on VS client to show this markdown content.

1 and 2 have been implemented as part of 2017 Interns project and released now. Please provide your feedback on the feature - both implemented and pending parts.

| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Package-README.md-support|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2280|

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Updates to the NuGet.org Terms of Use" (#8) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, we’re updating the NuGet.org Terms of Use and Privacy Statement. As we [announced](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) two weeks ago, the NuGet.org service is now a part of Microsoft. The NuGet open source codebase (both the NuGet gallery and the NuGet client) will remain open source and continue as .NET Foundation supported projects under the same terms as before.

We encourage you to read the full [Terms of Use](https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and [Privacy Statement](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839), as well as the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) about the changes. For your convenience, below is a quick summary.

There are no changes to the way you publish and consume packages from NuGet.org. The Terms of Use and Privacy Statement have been updated to reflect the change in ownership, as well as how Microsoft will process the data collected, and manage copyright and trademark infringement notices.

Our goal is to provide an agile and reliable global service, and we remain fully committed to ensuring a healthy and open ecosystem around NuGet. The .NET Foundation and Microsoft want NuGet to meet the evolving needs of our community. For questions about our policies, please contact us by email at [feedback@nuget.org](mailto:feedback@nuget.org?subject=Regarding%20updates%20to%20the%20NuGet.org%20Terms%20of%20Use).
